events.title: Admiral of the Fleet Submits Key Despatch to Admiralty Amidst WWII Tensions
events.description: The following Despatch was submitted to the Lords Commissioners of the Admiralty on the 17th July, 1940, by Admiral of the Fleet the Earl of Cork and Orrery, G.C.B., G.C.V.0., Flag Officer, Narvik.

events.title: Naval Gunfire Boosts 8th Army's Seaward Flank, WARSPITE's Catania Bombardment Marks Key Moment
events.description: 41. Much use was made of naval gunfire to support the seaward flank of the 8th Army. Reports showed that such support was satisfactory and effective. Only on one occasion was heavy ship gunfire employed, when WARSPITE carried out a brief bombardment of Catania on the evening of the 17th July.

events.title: Augusta Channel Cleared After E-Boat Scare; Convoys Resume Operations
events.description: Augusta. The presence of two E-boats in the searched channel during the night 16th/ 17th July caused minelaying to be suspected. Convoy movements were held up until 0930 when the port was re-opened after a 100 per cent. sweep of the channel over a width of two cables on either side of the centre line had been completed without disclosing a mine of any type.

events.title: New Regulations to Separate Guns and Fighters: A Bold Move for Operational Clarity
events.description: 8x. I came to the conclusion that the only solution was to give guns and fighters freedom each in their own sphere. On the roth July, therefore, I decided to prohibit fighters from entering the gun-belt, whatever the circumstances, after the 17th July. At a conference held to discuss this change, General Pile pointed out that an obvious corollary to it was to move all the guns inside the belt, so as to have them all in one place and provide both guns and fighters with clearly-defined spheres of operation. The logic of this argument was irrefutable; and I agreed to examine detailed proposals for moving all the guns into the belt except a few which would remain on the coast to act as   markers  .

events.title: Historic Capture: Caltagirone and Piazza Armerina Fall to Allied Forces in July 1943
events.description: | War Office footnote  According to official records, Caltagirone was captured at o4o0 hours, 16th July, 1943, and Piazza Armerina at o600 hours, 17th July, 1943.

events.title: Victorious Withdrawal: Indian Divisions Secure Strategic Gains Before Rest and Refit
events.description: 36. On the 17th July, 20 Indian Division was withdrawn from the Ukhrul sector after destroying the remnant, about 300 strong, of this Japanese force and capturing all its guns -and transport. The Division was now concentrated to rest and refit about Wanjing, 16 miles south-east of Imphal, where it could, if necessary, easily move in either direction and act as a reserve to 23 Indian Division on the Tamu road or to 5 and 17 Indian Divisions about Bishenpur. 50 Indian Parachute Brigade (two battalions) which had been operating most successfully on the flank of 20 Indian Division across the tracks running south from the Imphal - Ukhrul road, was similarly withdrawn for rest and re-organization in India.

events.title: Indian Divisions Forge Ahead: Strategic Gains in Pratomagno and Tiber Valley
events.description: is the equally roadless, longer and slightly higher massif of the Pratomagno. 1q Corps now had two Indian infantry divisions, 4th and roth, and an armoured brigade and on its extreme right two armoured car regiments, 12 Lancers and the Household Cavalry, operating in the tangled country between Gubbio and Fabriano. On 17th July 4 Indian Division captured the Alpe di Poti, north of the ArezzoSansepolcro road and on r8th July 4/10 Baluchis of ro Indian Division cleared Monte Cedrone, west of Citta di Castello in the Tiber valley, a strong position which had delayed our advance here since the 13th. events.title: Strategic Military Maneuvers: British Armoured Division Reinforces Eighth Army for Major Offensive in Italy
events.description: be reinforced by 1 British Armoured Division which was arriving in the country. For the moment, until arrangements for forward maintenance could be perfected, these forces were to concentrate in the general area of Assisi with some elements to the west near Siena. On 17th July Eighth Army Headquarters produced a detailed appreciation. The conclusions were that the attack should be made by two Corps, each with two divisions forward, operating up the axes Florence-Firenzuola and FlorenceBologna, The Poles were to hold on the Adriatic coast and would be connected with the central front by a Corps with a defensive r le. A cover-plan had already been put into force by my headquarters on 3rd July to suggest to the enemy that the main attack would come on the Adriatic coast.
